content.description:
A fun variation of Tigerlilly Right where you start in the dihedral and then bust left onto Tigerlilly Right, finishing on that boulder. Maybe saves you a couple of thin moves at the bottom of Tigerlilly Right.

My friend says that it is a little easier than straight up Tigerlilly Right, but I felt the difference in difficulty was subtle. Seems like the tricky thing is figuring out where to cut left, as you can easily end up with hands awkwardly crossed and on the wrong edges.
content.location: On the Tigerlilly boulder, at Bridge Free camp site boulders. Look for the cool dihendral, charge up the corner for about ten feet, then cut left onto the gorgeous face and finish on Tigerlilly Right.

content.description: This route is the scariest problem on the boulder. It starts on a large shelf with no feet, and moves up the thinning rail to crimps, topping out straight up. Take care through the crux moves near the top.
content.protection: A few pads and a spotter.
content.location: Start on the left face of the boulder, the obvious ledge. Climb straight up.

content.description: Use a heel hook and a toe jam to make it up to the seam, then continue upwards.
content.location: Start hugging the left arete of Tigerlily on the huge foot ledge with a big left hand sidepull and a small right-facing edge. Climb straight up the arete using the tree to topout.

content.description: Right side of Tigerlily boulder. Amazing!
content.location: Go on the trail past the free site parking lot towards the river. cut right and continue above the river for ~5 minutes.

content.description: Up the left side of the beautiful Tigerlily boulder with a somewhat committing move to the jug at the lip. There is now a fallen tree above the boulder, but the topout is fine if you traverse right.
content.protection: A few pads. Beware of the tree.
